title: Cape Cod adopts transfer fee on home sales over $1 million
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Barnstable County Assembly voted 10-5 to approve a home sales transfer fee over $1 million, aiming for $60 million annually.
The measure now awaits approval from the state legislature and would allow towns to adopt the fee through local votes.
Revenue from the fee would fund housing initiatives, with 90% returning to towns for local housing efforts.

title: Peabody police warn about ‘Northshore Mall takeover’
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Peabody police are on high alert for a 'Northshore Mall takeover' planned for Friday at 3 p.m.
The event involves large crowds, vehicle takeovers, and could potentially escalate with public safety risks, police stated.
Governor Maura Healey condemned such events, and proposed legislation aims to confiscate vehicles involved in takeovers.

title: 7 members of ‘Harvard Street Gang’ face drug and firearms charges, authorities say
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Seven members of the Harvard Street Gang charged with drug and firearm offenses in Eastern Massachusetts.
Authorities seized 25 firearms, kilograms of drugs, and tens of thousands in cash during coordinated raids.
Investigation since 2019 linked gang to shootings and drug distribution in Brockton and Randolph.

title: Al Horford says his decision to leave Celtics was ‘deeper than just the basketball’
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Al Horford signed with the Golden State Warriors after leaving the Boston Celtics in the offseason.
Horford mentioned non-basketball reasons influenced his decision to leave Boston, but details remain undisclosed.
Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla praised Horford's impact and character during his time with the team.

title: Readers agree: Build a new Madison Park to benefit Boston’s youth
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Boston.com readers support rebuilding Madison Park Technical Vocational High School on the 7.7-acre parcel P-3 in Roxbury.
The vocational school's redevelopment is seen as beneficial for providing students with career training without college debt.
Readers emphasize the need for improved educational facilities in Boston, citing outdated infrastructure in public schools.

title: Planned Parenthood rolls out vasectomies at Mass. health centers
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts now offers vasectomies at its Worcester location, responding to increased demand for permanent contraception.
The service was introduced with a Valentine's Day campaign to promote male contraception and emphasize shared responsibility in pregnancy prevention.
Increased vasectomy demand aligns with growing contraception interest post-Dobbs decision and recent election, highlighting reproductive health service pressures.

title: Body of Eastham man who fell through ice located after days of searching
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Gerard Boucher's body was found nearly a week after he fell through ice at First Encounter Beach, Eastham.
Kathleen Boucher fell through the ice with her husband on February 14; her body was recovered the same day.
Eastham police thank multiple regional partners for their efforts in searching for and recovering Gerard Boucher.

title: MSP trooper dragged by vehicle during East Boston stop
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Massachusetts State Police trooper dragged 10-20 feet by a car in East Boston during a traffic stop.
The driver, Binit Bikram Shah, 27, was arrested in New Hampshire and faces multiple charges including DUI.
MSP plans to charge Shah with assault and battery with a dangerous weapon and on a police officer.

title: Here’s why readers support voter ID laws, even as some take issue with SAVE America Act
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: The SAVE America Act mandates proof of citizenship and photo ID for federal voter registration and voting.
Massachusetts officials criticize the bill for potentially disenfranchising voters lacking necessary documentation, despite support for ID laws.
Readers expressed strong opinions on voter ID, with some preferring alternative methods over the proposed SAVE Act.

title: Mack Hollins fell just short of a stat worth $400K in incentives. The Patriots paid it anyway.
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Mack Hollins missed a $400,000 incentive for 50 catches, finishing with 46 due to injury.
The Patriots paid Hollins the $400,000 incentive despite missing two games with a lacerated spleen.
Hollins led Patriots in receiving yards during the AFC Championship and scored in the Super Bowl loss.
